name: higaisa

procedures: T1001.003::[Higaisa] used a FakeTLS session for C2 communications.
T1016::[Higaisa] used ipconfig to gather network configuration information.
T1027.001::[Higaisa] performed padding with null bytes before calculating its hash.
T1027::[Higaisa] used Base64 encoded compressed payloads.
T1029::[Higaisa] sent the victim computer identifier in a User-Agent string back to the C2 server every 10 minutes.
T1036.004::[Higaisa] named a shellcode loader binary svchast.exe to spoof the legitimate svchost.exe.
T1041::[Higaisa] exfiltrated data over its C2 channel.
T1053.005::[Higaisa] dropped and added officeupdate.exe to scheduled tasks.
T1057::[Higaisa]’s shellcode attempted to find the process ID of the current process.
T1059.003::[Higaisa] used cmd.exe for execution.
T1059.005::[Higaisa] has used VBScript code on the victim's machine.
T1059.007::[Higaisa] used JavaScript to execute additional files.
T1071.001::[Higaisa] used HTTP and HTTPS to send data back to its C2 server.
T1082::[Higaisa] collected the system volume serial number, GUID, and computer name.
T1090.001::[Higaisa] discovered system proxy settings and used them if available.
T1106::[Higaisa] has called various native OS APIs.
T1124::[Higaisa] used a function to gather the current time.
T1140::[Higaisa] used certutil to decode Base64 binaries at runtime and a 16-byte XOR key to decrypt data.
T1203::[Higaisa] has exploited CVE-2018-0798 for execution.
T1204.002::[Higaisa] used malicious e-mail attachments to lure victims into executing LNK files.
T1220::[Higaisa] used an XSL file to run VBScript code.
T1547.001::[Higaisa] added a spoofed binary to the start-up folder for persistence.
T1564.003::[Higaisa] used a payload that creates a hidden window.
T1566.001::[Higaisa] has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious attachments.
T1573.001::[Higaisa] used AES-128 to encrypt C2 traffic.
T1574.002::[Higaisa]’s JavaScript file used a legitimate Microsoft Office 2007 package to side-load the OINFO12.OCX dynamic link library.

description: [Higaisa](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0126) is a threat group suspected to have South Korean origins. [Higaisa](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0126) has targeted government, public, and trade organizations in North Korea; however, they have also carried out attacks in China, Japan, Russia, Poland, and other nations. [Higaisa](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0126) was first disclosed in early 2019 but is assessed to have operated as early as 2009.(Citation: Malwarebytes Higaisa 2020)(Citation: Zscaler Higaisa 2020)(Citation: PTSecurity Higaisa 2020)
